description:
An all around wondeful dining experience that exceeded my family and my expectations.   

We've always wanted to try Rue Lepic.  We would walk by, drive by, and have wanted to come for YEARS!  The restaurant is often full, and several times, we've tried for walk in but to no avail.  

Today, we once again were wondering where to dine for dinner and thought of Rue Lepic once again.  We called the restaurant and we're able to reserve for 6:30!  So excited!!  

From the moment we walked in and greeted by Marco's bright smile and warm welcome, to tasting Chef Michiko's wondeful food and also greeted by her (LOVE, LOVE, LOVE chefs who come out from the kitchen and talk to diners!!!), to tasing our desserts and walking out the door full and satisfied... our experience was excellent from end to end.

We learned that Rue Lepic has been here for 37 years!  AND, the Chef Michiko and Maitre 'd/ waiter / do-it-all amazing Marco team has been together for 35!!!  Even marriages don't last this long!   But this wondeful duel amazes me...  with a 2pp team, they're able to execute everything seamlessly.  From timing the food perfectly, waiting for patrons to come back out from washroom, to picking up plates and refilling water.  Nothing was missed or delayed.  Amazing!!!  

What makes dining here so enjoyable is especially Marco... I still remember his bright warm smile.  "Thank you very much", I would say.  And he would say "you're welcome very much."  It's not just the words but his upbeat, bright, warm smile.  You can tell that they truly enjoy their jobs here.  

During our dining, Chef Michiko came out from her open kitchen to introduce herself.  Asked us how we liked our food... we loved it(!!!) and proceeded to also welcome other tables.  So rare these days are chefs who still
take the time to greet customers.  I truly enjoy this restaurant.

Ok, now on to the food:

* Rack of Lamb
We heard that the rack of lamb is excellent here so 3 out of the 4 of us opted for this dish.  It's one of the best i've had....  juicy, tasty, well seasoned, and moist and tender.  Highly recommended.

* Creme of Vegetable Soup
Came with entree... very tasty.  Not overly creamy or salty like many places.  You can taste the vegetable and I love the small kick in spices to make this soup spicy.  

* Seafood Pasta
Everything is perfect about this dish.  The el dante pasta, the excellent sauce covering every strand of angel hair, the well seasoned seafood.  Perfect.  Well, except maybe the dish is too small... lol

* Caesar Salad 
Good solid caesar salad  

* Fresh Garden Salad
Excellent garden salad - usually this is the house, blah, bland salad but not at Rue Lepic.  I would opt for this one instead of the Caesar

* Creme Brûlée 
SO GOOD!!  One of the best I've had .  It's mild, it's fresh, it's light and the creme is not overpowering . All around excellent!!

We're so happy we finally dined here and can't wait to be back.
author: Winnie W.

description:
Meh

The food was fine but the service leaves quite a bit to be desired. The wait staff don't know how to wait on tables.  They're just untrained folks schlepping food from the kitchen, truthfully.  I hate to be so blunt. No social grace. No etiquette. We expected more from a place that's been here for decades. Especially given what you're paying. I honestly don't know why people come here unless it's the only French restaurant in the neighborhood. 

Pass. 

There are other French restaurants to enjoy.
author: Christopher M.

description:
A pleasant neighborhood French restaurant, but not wowing, especially for the price. Some dishes were delightful, others needed better prep to make the meat either more flavorful or more tender. 

While they carry young, nom-noteworthy wines by label, the price wasn't bad and the taste was delightful (in a relaxing summer kind of way, but not in a mature, sommelier paired kind of way).
author: Art W.

description:
Omg. 
What a dream. 
My friend took me here. He knows I'm so picky about food. I can't eat everything. So limited. 
But I finished all my dishes. We had the fixed menu which you still have options to choose. 
Pasta with clam and shrimp cane first. Delicious. 
Vegetarian soup of the day cane second. Delicious. 
Ceasar Salad came third. Delicious. 
My main course was veal which I wanted well done and it was delicious. My friends was filet and it was delicious. 
For my main course before it comes I was worried because I don't like any meat. It shouldn't smell.....  but it was gooooood. Marco was our servant. He is amazing, I looked around, he knew I want peooer. How?!?? 
Dessert  delicious and what a great night and great service. 
I loved the open kitchen. You can see the chef cooking there.  She was a sweetheart. So focus abd peaceful. I love to go back and I recommend this restaurant to all my friends. 
For weekends you better get reservation. 
Enjoy!
author: Hani G.

description:
I was recently asked during an ice-breaker what my favorite place in my hometown (San Francisco) is, and my IMMEDIATE answer without a moment's hesitation was Rue Lepic. 

To say this place is a real life dream is an understatement. I dream about this food in my sleep. 

Highly highly highly recommend the seafood pasta appetizer - it tastes like heaven! I also recommend the chicken main course and either the cheesecake or chocolate ganache for dessert. I have come here dozens of times and have tried almost everything on their menu, and have NEVER been disappointed. Their soups (which they pair all main courses with) are also DIVINE!

I always leave this place licking each plate, feeling as though I just left a fairytale. 

The ambience and atmosphere of this charming little restaurant is just beyond magical. 

If you want to taste and experience real heaven, this is the place for you!

Every visit here is just a dream and each time I plan to go, I spend the entire week counting down and daydreaming about it. 

Favorite place in San Francisco and maybe, just maybe favorite place in the entire world!
author: Anna B.

description: Was excited to try this restaurant. The atmosphere is quaint, like being in the chef's kitchen. Ate there last nite and must say I was disappointed in the lamb. It didn't have much taste or flavor. Service was a bit slow and it seemed like there was only one waitperson for the entire room. Unfortunately won't be going back.
author: Jackie N.

description:
I was afraid the same waiter that greeted us would be serving us, but thank God a very soft spoken, kind and attentive gentlemen took our order and served our food. 

My girl told me that this was the BEST restaurant she had eaten at years ago, so my expectations were very high, which I don't like. What can I say, I'm a set-your-expectations-low kind of guy. She was so right tho. The food was  TO DIE FOR. 

Love the ambiance and the small setting. Very intimate, very delicious. Shout out to my boy Ken for the awesome service, sweet demeanor and words of wisdom.
author: Jacob C.

description:
A comfortable neighborhood spot in the lower Nob Hill area.  It has been around for around 30 years and one of those rapidly disappearing San Francisco neighborhood restaurants while trendy places take over.

This place isn't large, perhaps a dozen tables tucked closely together.  It is showing its age, but consider it patina.

This was the second time I've been here and similar experiences both times.  Both times we came with friends.

We had a reservation and were seated right away. The restaurant seems to have a steady clientele and some were know by the staff.

I started with the escargot appetizer, served without the shell on capellini pasta and a sauce.  It is delcious and well worth trying, for its unusual presentation alone.

We all got asparagus soup and it too was excellent.

What I admired is the French bread they serve-.REAL French bread, with a very light flakey crust that crumbles easily.  You don't find it very often in these parts.  The only downside is you each get a couple pieces, no more.

My main course was the duck l'orange. It was tender in slices with a brown sauce poured over it.  We all agreed that the true test of good entrees is the quality of the carrots when served.  These were excellent.

We ordered wine and everyone enjoyed the entire meal.

This appears to be a family operation where they all work.  The kitchen is open to the room so you can see everything if facing it.  The woman cooking appears to have it all down to a science.

The staff is very friendly, but do get harried sometimes too.  Don't come if you have time constraints.  Things move at its own pace. It seemed like a long wait to get our entrees, but we didn't mind.

I would definitely go back.  It's a good place to eat and a remaining vestige of long term neighborhood restaurants in the City.
author: Tom B.

description:
Loved our dinner here. Its a small, cozy place so definitely make a reservation and wouldn't recommend coming here with more than 4 people. Open kitchen which smelled amazing. In short, definitely coming back again for the five course Prix fixe with lobster tail. 

Atmosphere - 5 stars. Whole vibe including how friendly the servers were is warm and cozy. Nice but not overly fancy or stuffy. 

Service - 10 stars. Our server was friendly and fun without being too much. Servers are attentive but busy and with one chef, pacing was leisurely (we got the five course Prix fixe which took about 2 hours). It made for an awesome date night with a lot of time to talk/catch up but just go in with the right expectations and make sure to allot enough time. 

Food - 4 stars. We did the five course Prix fixe which was $62-$67 depending on your entree. In general, everything the chef touched was delicious (seafood pasta, soup, entrees) and everything else (salad, dessert) was average/good but nothing special.  Appetizer sized portion of seafood pasta (AMAZING), soup of the day (we had something green that was also amazing), caesar or garden salad, entree (lobster tail was amazing, duck breast was okay) and dessert (creme brulee and cheesecake were okay). 

Drinks - Don't know enough about wine to rate but they have a limited menu of domestic and imported wines and the one we ended up with was good.
author: Sarina Y.

description:
We were lucky enough to find this local gem for our anniversary dinner. We were not disappointed!!! 

Excellent food!!! Amazing service!!! Quaint, cozy, friendly, quiet, and an amazing overall experience.

We would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone and will absolutely return whenever possible. 

Thanks you folks for an incredible evening and memory. 

George and Lisa
author: George H.

description:
This place is only open in the evenings. We walked in right when it opened and were sat down immediately. I'd suggest making a reservation on the weekends. 

I ordered the duck. It was cooked to perfection and I enjoyed everything on the plate. However, I wish there were more vegetables. 

Customer service was excellent!

Street parking is available and the restaurant is located in a neighborhood so parking is come and go.
author: Ami S.

description: Very traditional French cafe; you've probably eaten each item on the menu sometime in your life.  It's good not great, like much of home cooking.  Low key ambience may be due to no alcoholic spirits, just beer and wine.  The wine list is reasonably priced.  Service is very pleasant but slow;  that may be due to the kitchen's pacing.  Two fixed price menus in the $60s are a good value if you want so many courses.  Not a destination but a neighborhood bistro.
author: Shelly G.

description: SF staple. Good food at a very fair price. Try the prix fix for the best bang for your buck.
author: Sammi C.

description:
Rue Lepic is a quintessential neighborhood restaurant in SF. We have been going there about one time a year for the last 30 years or so. Neither the cuisine nor the service has ever disappointed us.
Most recently we took our 6 year old granddaughter there for dinner following a busy day showing her the highlights of SF. The service was impeccable and the menu gave us great choices. I had the veal chop and my wife had the lamb chops. Our granddaughter ordered (and finished!) the salmon. The entrees were well prepared and delicious. 
But, the highlight of the meal was the chocolate desert, which we all shared. The desert was served with a small glass of complimentary port.
All in all a really nice and authentic dining experience in a City that knows great dining.
author: Robert H.

description:
Very good cute I would go back I'm not sure how French it is .
Upstairs needs a little better service
author: Michael P.

description:
The foods are decent.  Not any restaurant, you can order sweetbreads and it's tasty enough for you not to feel like you're eating an organ.  The lamb and veal are decent as well.  The duck was fine but the sauce wasn't a choice I would choose.  Soup of the day is interesting and sides of green beans and carrots are okay.  We didn't stay for desserts because we wanted to catch the Ritz-Carlton lobby bar before they close.

We had good service.  Amazing they can put out all the entrees and foods with that teeny tiny kitchen.
author: Kayla N.

description: Had a great evening at this restaurant. Made a reservation for a Tuesday night at 8pm. The place was a little upscale (we were underdressed). We were served bread followed by soup before our main course. I ordered the salmon with lemon sauce. The salmon plate was decently large, and the lemon sauce was the perfect mixture of tangy and creamy. Ordered crème brûlée for dessert, which was delicious but a rather small portion and arguably not worth the $9. I would eat here again if I had another tech company meal stipend to blow. Also should add that the waiter was actually French :)
author: Alexis F.

description:
Dined at Rue Lepic on Jan. 24, 2018. The restaurant is quite small, and the decor doesn't have much charm. 

My wife and I both had the prix fixe offering. My wife chose the lobster tail entree, and I chose the roasted veal. 

The seafood pasta was very enjoyable. The soup of the day was cream of cauliflower, and was also well done. The garden salad was fine, with a nice dressing. My roasted veal was enjoyable, with a delicious mushroom and truffle sauce. 

My wife's lobster tail was a disappointment, however. She says it had been in the freezer for far too long, and the taste and texture were off. 

We both had the chocolate ganache for dessert, and agreed that it was way too sweet. The fruits and berries may have been a better choice.

We would have liked some more bread, but none was offered, which we thought surprising.
author: Captain B.

description: Love the quaint atmosphere of this restaurant. The salmon and veal were fantastic. Small wine list yet enough variety. Definitely one to keep on the short list.
author: Robert C.

description:
One woman wonder behind that kitchen, it was insane. The food was EXCELLENT, totally had a homecooked element to it. Absolutely delicious soup as well. It was quite excellent. 

Service was atrocious...I would give 3 stars to the place as a whole but food is more important. Servers are quick to bring the check but not water refills. Come on guys...do your jobs than chatting around!!!
author: Michael L.

description:
A special little bistro - intimate setting, attentive service and delicious simple food well cooked. 
The vegetable soup was very tasty (my husband finished it, and he does not usually like soup!), the filet mignon and veal were tender, flavoursome and accompanied by tasty sauces and the desserts (chocolate ganache and creme brûlée) were done perfectly. Highly recommend for a special meal in San Francisco!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I think we may have come on an 'off' night or maybe  we just don't know any better. I would like to rate higher but given our experience, it's a little hard.

We dined on a Saturday night for an early 6 pm dinner. The restaurant squeezed (literally; it's a tiny place) us in even though they were booked with reservations. Btw, they told us the table would be needed at 7:30 pm. No problem, so we thought.

We ordered within about 10 minutes of sitting down. The escargots appetizer took about 40 minutes. Then our entrees of veal and duck arrived about 20 minutes later. The food was room temperature. I told the waitress and she offered to have the food heated up. Since we had been waiting over an hour, I declined the offer.

The pros: the food was really good. The waitress was very friendly and offered samples of a few wines for choosing.
The cons: tiny restaurant, slow service, limited menu, and since the kitchen is in the restaurant, you'll smell like dinner.
author: Ana M.

description:
Before coming to the restaurant, I read a lot of fantastic reviews about this restaurant. Probably because of the high expectation, I can only give a four star here. We are in a meat state lately, so despite of the great reviews on the chef's menu of the seafood pasta, we ordered the filet Mignon and roasted veal chop. The filet mignon was perfectly cooked, it's great but within my expectation. The vegetables on the side was standard, the sauce was a little overwhelming but good. However, the veal chop was a little disappointing, it's a bit dried up and over cooked. The side vegetables were exactly the same as the filet mignon, feels a little redundant. It's the standard of Ruth Chris Steak House, but with a special little French restaurant in nob hills area in San Francisco, I was expecting a little more. 
There are so many great french baguette in the world, but the house bread here tastes and feels like days old bread being reheated inappropriately. Hope this is not consistently so. 
The soup of the day was asparagus soup. It's too salty and plain at the same time. Nothing special at all.
Over all it's a good meal within my expectation. Nothing beyond.
author: Chelsea B.

description: This little place is incredible. Tight, small little place. Remarkable cuisine. Not inexpensive, so if you're looking for "cheap eats" please don't go and take my table. This is finely crafted French cuisine of a level you rarely see in California. This restaurant would be at home in New Orleans or New York. Do go, take your time. Enjoy!
author: Armando Z.

description: What an unexpected surprise!  We stayed at the Mark Hopkins and noticed Rue Lepic on our walk to downtown. We stopped for dinner on our way back. It is beautiful, quaint and immaculate. The owner/chef is lovely. As well as the servers! And the food was absolutely exceptional! We had the escargot which were made with angel hair pasta with a delicious light tomato sauce. We then had a wonderful light cream of vegetable soup. Our entrees were the sweetbread which were the best we've ever had! And the veal and truffle sauce was delectable! And we finished with a crepe brûlée which again was one of the best we ever tried. This is definitely one of the best restaurants we have been to in San Francisco!! And we will certainly be visiting again soon!!
author: Patti A.

description:
Had a dinner here with a colleague and food and wine pairings were great. Ordered the grilled chicken breast with a nice Bordeaux Cab and the combination was marvelous. 

The greatest thing about the night was we witnessed a poor girl having her phone stolen right in front of the restaurant and the amount of patrons in the restaurant that offered to be a eyewitness to the police was great. When the officer came into the restaurant asking if anybody witnessed what happened and to describe the suspect, immediately 6 people in the restaurant gave their account.  Also shout out to the one guy who wine outside and called 911 and helped the poor girl. What do they put in their food to make such awesome people. 

Not that it matters, i felt very young in this restaurant. Thanks!
author: Milad S.

description:
Being a bit of a connoisseur of French cuisine, I  am a classically trained chef, this place intrigued me. I  had read some of the reviews and had to check it out. Being from out of town, I got two of my colleagues to come with me. Love this area of the city. Loved the restaurant itself. True old school place. The chef is on top of her game.  Two of us had veal with truffle and mushroom sauce. Perfectly cooked veal and the sauce looked beautiful and tasted absolutely fabulous. Our waiter, what a treat. He knew the food, he knew the wine, he was attentive without hovering. 
After a day full of meetings to be able to come to this relaxed atmosphere and enjoy an incredible meal was just what we all needed. It is definitely on my Return To list. Well done .
author: Richard L.

description: I've been dining at Rue Lepic on special occasions for 20 years, and it is still one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. It sits 300 feet from the Intercontinental Mark Hopkins Hotel and is the perfect choice when friends fly into town and are staying on Nob Hill. Go for the 5-course meal which is now $62. This is a $$$-$$$$ restaurant according to several guides, but I don't believe $62 for 5-courses is high priced. This is especially true when you have a choice of entrées that include filet mignon au poivre vert, duck a l'orange, rack of lamb with garlic and mint beurre rouge, salmon with dill, and the fresh fish of the day. Everything is always prepared to perfection. The other courses are a salad, either mixed greens or a classic Caesar, a seafood cappellini, a vegetable pottage, and your choice of six different desserts, including crème brûlée, a dense chocolate mouse (la ganache au chocolate), passionfruit mousse, cheesecake, and fresh berries with creme anglais. I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Dennis C.

description:
Gerardo is so awesome!! He's a one man show. I had such a lovely meal with my sister here. My seafood pasta was so flavorful and delicious. The Mushroom soup was Devine. My  Caesar salad was so tasty . My Lobster tail was decadent and had a yummy sauce. Then when the cheesecake came I couldn't believe how perfect. The lovely back of house crew was excellent as well. All the windows looking at the rain start and stop was just awesome!!! Great spot, great date spot too. Cozy, quaint and classy with excellent service.
Thank you.
author: Cecilia D.

description: What an amazing dinner. For years I've driven by and always wanted to eat here. We had a show at the. Masonic and I remembered this place is nearby. They open at 5:30 and our show started at 7 so I was concerned that we would have enough time. I called to make the reservation and let them know we didn't have a lot of time and they said "no problem". Incredibly we had a delicious french 4 course meal in an hour. The service was spectacular. Our friendly server would bring out each course a couple of minutes after we finished the other course. The soup and salad were very fresh and tasty. I had the lamb chops and they were perfect. I don't like mint but I couldn't taste it. My husband had the filet mignon and it looked so good. However, dessert was the best. I had the chocolate ganache that was like eating frosting. I will return.
author: Claudia M.

description: I have not eaten at many French restaurants recently, so I might not be the best judge here, but we had a lovely experience at this restaurant.  I tried one of the prix fixe offerings, and my wife had the chicken.  French, to me, is all about the sauces and soups, and these were superb.  The consistency and flavor of the spinach soup made me wish I had a tureen of it!  The truffle sauce on the veal was delicious and playful, with a touch of sweetness to match the veal.  Unfortunately, the veal was very average and slightly overcooked, but I haven't good veal in the states.  I wish I had gone for the duck or lobster.  Service was perfect, the dishes arriving with a comfortable pause between courses, and a visit from the head chef.  When they found out if was my birthday, they even comped the corkage.  I will definitely return.
author: Montag F.

description: Very romantic little Nob Hill treasure. It's a bit of a walk, hence the name "The Peak", but wow...I realized about the 3rd bite I had no need to ever order steak again. I ordered the Filet mignon. I couldn't cut the prices any smaller to make this experience last. I wished that first bite would last forever. The soup was cream of zucchini...excellent, the bread was perfect portion and quality, and I don't know what The French do with butter but I'm telling you...this was amazing, all of it. My waitress, Arintna, was fabulous, Michihiro was most gracious. I assured them I would return...after my food coma subsides.
author: Rodney M.

description: Good food at reasonable prices. Had the lamb this time. The duck is also very good. Cozy location. Nice neighbourhood. Definitely will be back.
author: Klaus W.

description: Ok it's that time again for me to rave about the brightest gem in the San Francisco food crown...Rue Lepic. This is a truly remarkable restaurant that serves amazing French inspired dishes and warm and attentive service. I can't reiterate this enough that you shouldn't miss the chance to dine here. I love this place and can't wait for my next trip to come back.
author: Jeff G.

description: Found this great restaurant tucked in neighborhood while walking in San Francisco. Service was understated and excellent. Never rushed and questions thoroughly answered. Caesar salad split in kitchen for us and served on chilled plates. Asparagus soup seasoned with dill and perfectly balanced flavors. My husband's duck was tender and cooked optimally to just under medium rare. I had salmon excellently prepared in white wine cream sauce that was flaky and not over cooked. Wine list not extensive but had nice selection in all price categories with many by the glass. Restaurant only seats about 25-30 so very intimate. Menu was limited but varied selections for fish and meats. Highly recommend Rue Lepic.
author: Cathy R.

description:
One of my favorite french restaurant in San Francisco! Parking isn't that good so make sure you get there early to find parking in the area. 
This was my second time there and absolutely enjoyed it both times. Last month I came here with my boyfriend for my birthday and made reservations at 8:30pm. We were seated right away once we got there. We were handed our menus and ordered a glass of sangria for myself.  We then ordered our food. Waiter explained to us the menu and food took maybe 20 minutes or so but luckily there was bread to eat while we waited. I had the lobster tail and it was da bomb!  My boyfriend had the lamb chops and that was good also! We had a salad, angel hair pasta (super tasty), lobster tail and a dessert. We had 3 desserts bc we like being a fat asses! We had the cheesecake and the raspberry mousse. So yummy!!   I need to go back there asap! Owner was also super generous and she thanked us for coming. 

Service was 5 stars. 
Food was 5 stars. 

Definitely will be back for some more!
author: Monica W.

description:
Nice
I ordered the escargot and seafood angel hair. 
A little French restaurant with friendly and romantic ambiance
author: Celia Z.

description:
Mediocre food. Harried service...which is odd for a restaurant that seats only 30. I know, maybe get the old guy to do something, too, or hire another waiter!

My chicken was warm at best, and looked like it was covered in vomit. I closed my eyes and it tasted okay. With all the great restaurants is SF, this one pales. Don't bother.
author: Marc J.

description: Small, cozy French restaurant with excellent food and friendly service. The prix fixe meal is excellent value (seafood pasta, soup, salad, entree, and dessert) and the wine list while not extensive, has a good variety. The seafood pasta (angel hair pasta with scallops and a light tomato-based sauce) was very tasty, the soup (vegetable with pureed potatoes, carrots, leeks, and spinach) delicious, and the salad crisp and fresh. There's a choice of house or Caesar for the salad and both were excellent. I had the duck a l'orange which was outstanding - just the right amount of sweetness - and a nice portion. My husband had the filet mignon with peppercorn sauce and it was very tasty and cooked exactly as he requested. Nice variety of deserts - I had the mixed fruit with creme Anglaise and my husband had the cheesecake. Both were the perfect finish to the meal. Add in a reasonable bottle of Chateauneuf-du-Pape and it was a memorable meal!
author: David C.

description:
I wish I could give Rue Lepic 6 stars. It's just that fabulous. Actually, it's that Epic. 

I visited with my mother and aunt, and we all ordered a different dish. All entrées were served with cauliflower soup. Let me begin with the soup - it was amazing. Puréed cauliflower soup seasoned to perfection and had me restraining myself from licking the bowl. Luckily I was able to sop it up with the delicious bread provided. Our fabulous waiter provided us the perfect recommendation for wine to pair with our meals. 

Now to the entrées. We are all lovers of food and well traveled. My aunt described her salmon as being the best she has ever tasted - we all agreed. My duck was cooked to perfection with an orange sauce that was a little sweet, a little savory and every bit amazing. The steak a poivre was just as amazing and rivaled any I have tasted in France. I again had to restrain myself from licking my plate. 

Then dessert. Oh my. Chocolate ganache with strawberry and kiwi sauce. The ganache was approximately the size of a golfball, and I thought to myself 'There is no way that will be enough for the three of us'...it was so rich and delicious we didn't even make it halfway through.

Takeaway: I will happily drive 3 hours into San Francisco to eat at Rue Lepic, and then drive right back home. It's just that Epic!
author: Krysta S.

description: The salmon with dill was incredible and I don't even like salmon... or dill.  They mix it with butter/ cream and capers and it comes out just scrumptious. Really excellent.  The pea soup is very good too, nice and creamy.
author: Mark S.

description: This place never disappoint us. All dishes were very yummy. My favorites are the seafood angel hair, veal, and rack of lamb. Creme brûlée is always good.
author: O L.

description: We came on a Saturday evening when the rush was dying down, the main waitress was in a hurry but extremely rude. Threw our bread on the plate, grabbed my bowl of soup before I was finished, forgot our salad, and rushed us out. The food was good, my experience was ruined by her obscene behavior. Would not recommend, there are other great French restaurants nearby.
author: Geetha R.

description:
Great service and location in Nob Hill. Plan for parking. This time we parked in a different lot and walked the grueling uphill towards restaurant so we would walk downhill back to car after dinner !

Our favorite waiter Vincent has retired , but this place holds find memories of birthday and anniversary celebrations.

Order the chef's tasting menu, which is worth it. We've been going to Rue Lepic for almost 20 years and their food is consistent. Bless the one chef/cook who knows how to time your dish will arrive timely and I. The right order. The restaurant is small and quaint, but she knows when to start preparing the dishes for approx 12-14 tables. 

The tasting menu includes:
- Seafood pasta with scallops, shrimp and a divine cream sauce
- Soup of the day (vegetarian)
- Garden or Cesar salad (fresh beets in garden salad yummy and so is Cesar)
- Entree: rack of lamb, beef fillet, duck, fish, sweetbreads and some others I can't recall served with asparagus/veggie and rice or scalloped potatoes 
- dessert: crowne brûlée, berries and cream (yummy!), chocolate ganache to name a few 

Definitely worth the price!
author: Rowi E.

description: My neighborhood absolute favorite - I feel extremely fortunate to have a homey restaurant so close to where I live. The restaurant is run by two elegant ladies, who preciously owned Venticello and Nob Hill cafe. The Chef's menu offers delicious lobster and seafood pasta. For appetizer, I recommend the escargot. After the meal, walk up to California street for a beautiful view of the city and Grace Cathedral.
author: Vivien S.

description: The food was beautiful! Starting from the soup to the tender meat. The place is a quaint little one tucked away in a quite street. We had a hiccup when we came in- we sat idly for a good 15 minutes without a menu or eye contact even. My partner stood up and went outside to make reservation at another restaurant, by then I got the attention of the waiter and it was smooth sailing. The wine was delicious and the soup was silky. The dessert was scrumptious as well. Overall a pleasant gastro experience. As an added touch, the chef, a cute little old lady made her way through the tables, personally making sure the food was satisfactory.
author: Trisha H.

description:
Good food great wine & excellent service! Would definite come again.
Intimate, relaxed atmosphere.
author: Dave F.

description:
Rúe lepic was absolutely delicious. We ordered the chef's 4 course meal and the best part is use can chose anyone of the entrees.

The sea food pasta, veel and filet mignon were the best. The ambience is formal and elegant and the service is nothing short of the best.

I would recommend this place for a first date or a special occasion
author: Nigel D.

description: Visited this place after a local friend recommended it to my husband and I. This place did not disappoint; it is truly a hidden gem. Seems like the 5 course deal is the best bang for your buck. We had lamb and the sweetbreads and both were delish! The creme brûlée was the best dessert offered and it too was scrumptious. Give this place a shot, it won't let you down.
author: Anahi G.

description:
Rue Lepic is my most favorite restaurant in San Francisco!  My boyfriend took me out to this restaurant by chance, and we have been satisfied customers for the past 3 years!  All of their entrees are delicious, and I highly recommend their Chef Menu.  It's a 5 course meal; both entree or lobster (costs a little bit more) option are great!  The Chef Menu comes with:

-Seafood pasta
-Soup of the day
-Garden or Caesar salad 
-Entree of your choice 
-Dessert of your choice

Fresh warm bread and butter is also served (seconds will be granted if asked!) Each course is a perfect quantity, and is full of rich flavors!

Vincent is a wonderful waiter!!  He is quite familiar with his regular customers and upholds the most accommodating service.  Rue Lepic's great food accompanied with Vincent's service (and of course the rest of the hard working staff) are the reasons why this place holds a special place in my heart.  I've had many wonderful nights here!

I definitely plan to be back soon!!
author: Midori L.

description: I found this restaurant through Yelp while in San Francisco for a trip. The restaurant is very cozy and the staff was great!  Marcos was our waiter, and was excellent!  I ordered the Filet Mignon and really enjoyed my meal. Presentation was very appealing, and portion was just right. Overall I really enjoyed my experience and will definitely be willing to go back when ever I am in town
author: Lazaro G.

description: We had the most magical and delicious dinner last night and we are still raving about the whole experience. The food was perfection, every flavor and texture sublime. The staff, head, chef and owner were beyond kind and gave us special attention throughout our birthday dinner. I cannot say enough about this restaurant, and will come again to sit in it's small intimate setting again and again.
author: CL G.

description:
Such yummy food. My husband and I have been coming here for years, both chefs are Great the owner and Adela. 

The restaurant is very small, very intimate but the food and the service is the best.
author: Alejandra P.

description:
My longtime favorite getaway and secret for special occasions.  While a bit hard to find, this tiny French bistro in the Tendernob is one of my favorites.  Took an old schoolmate here a few weeks ago.

We ordered one of two prix-fix choices.  She had the lamb chops, I enjoyed the filet mignon. Our desserts were superb - chocolate ganache and creme brûlée - yet the soup de jour (mushroom) was the best!

While it was very busy, the waiter was very accommodating. And the wine was exceptionally priced! (Shhh..don't let this get out).
author: hugh c.

description: Traditional French-style cuisine in an intimate (but not necessarily romantic) atmosphere.  Terrific seafood pasta.  Excellent fish of the day (Rockfish). Passion fruit mousse blew me away with its texture and brightness.  Not so good: bland watercress soup served barely lukewarm.  Super attentive service.  Lots of butter and cream sauces.  The menu offers two pre-fixe choices.  No chance of leaving hungry.  With wine and a generous tip, count on $90 per person.
author: David S.

description: If you love French food. That is he place you have to try. But there are only few option in the menu
author: Ying D.

description:
Great place with an intimate setting. We had the escargot to start with a paired wine. For the entree, I had perfectly cooked duck. For desert, a cream brûlée.

My favorite thing about this restaurant was how the chef came out and asked us how the food was. It definitely made the experience better.
author: Justin J.

description:
I don't know why everyone is raving about this place.  It's really not that great.  I feel bad giving them a 2 star rating because the service was really good but the food was meh! 

First, the dishes aren't anything to write about especially for the prices.  Is this a really expensive place. No.  But it isn't cheap either and for the price and quality there are so many better French restaurants in San Francisco.  

Cons:  
Butter is blah - not homemade which most true French Restaurants prepare
Bread is not worth eating and yet it's a FRENCH restaurant 
Duck a l'Orange was way over cooked.  The sauce was lacking character, flavor or love.  The side dishes (rice, green beans and carrots) were the quality of a line cook at your school cafeteria
Rack of Lamb - Sauce was nothing special.  The sides were the exact same as the Duck.  

Pros: 
Service was great
Easy Parking 
Quite restaurant

In the Middle:  
Rack of Lamb was well done but only because my husband requested it med. rare.  The recommended way to prepare it was med.  BIG RED FLAG  

So you can easily conclude that my experience at Rue Lepic was not fantastic.  Would I eat here again.  NO.  

French Restaurants that are FAR superior: 
Nico 
Chapeau 
Baker Street Bistro 
and of course the BEST- La Folie
author: Lexie S.

description: Been coming here every time I visit SF.   One of the city's best restaurants.  Closest thing to a Parisian Bistro in the US.  Food is consistently excellent and very fairly priced.
author: John M.

description:
GUESS WHO JUST TURNED 21?!

I'm a big girl now! and my big butt needs feeding, and for my birthday, the boy decided to be a little reminiscent so we showed up here!

The temperature, uncomfortably hot. Interesting enough, I was so flustered that I wanted to play footsie with the boytoy but contained myself. 

The vibe, cozy and intimate. The restroom's the most intimate part though, I was practically hugging myself in there. 

The food, satisfying. 

Just to be a little serious here: 
Seafood Pasta: very aromatic and flavorful sauce; a bit runny however; would have preferred a thicker sauce IF it was an entree but since it was an appetizer, the lighter sauce was very fitting; the shrimp and scallop (though small bite sizes) were very crispy and fresh--none of that soggy wet mushy alien meat
Cream of Watercress: good. I say good and nothing else because cream of anything tastes the vaguely the same to me...i.e: cream of asparagus, cream of broccoli, cream of watercress... i've always believed that it's the rich buttery cream taste people liked.
Caesar Salad: slightly too much dressing; I liked how the parmesan wasn't overpoweringly strong
Rack of Lamb: the boy liked, me thinks mehh.. I like my rack of lamb crusty on the outside and a very pink, almost red center; this was a little too saucy for me. 
Lobster Tail: DROOL. that butter...that garlic... that bed of sliced potatoes... makes you just want to savor the flavor in your mouth and not eat anything else after!
Cheesecake: the boy likes more than mousse.
Chocolate Mousse: i like more than cheesecake. its quite bitter but very very rich and very very dark. *wink wink* 


Come hungry, my friends... and leave the diet behind.
author: Nadeen H.

description: I have rarely enjoyed a meal as much as my recent dinner at Rue Lepic. Some of that, certainly, was the company of friends and family,  but the cooking was elegant and the atmosphere friendly.  I enjoyed a spectacular piece of salmon for my entree and a really nice creme brulee with raspberries for dessert. The meal, with wine and tip, was $288 for 7 people - very reasonable for a nice restaurant in a big city. Warning: the one bathroom is the smallest room I have ever been in - NOT kidding.
author: Marc D.

description:
I live next door and like to come here for dinners with friends when I'm keen to make a meal the focus of the evening -- but when I'm not in the mood for a hassle getting somewhere, waiting, or getting a reservation. I always get the chef's menu, and I've never been disappointed with the food or service.

Basic interior. Space is a bit tight, as well, and noise from the kitchen and ventilation are frequently in the background. Normally, I'd drop a place to three stars for that, but the food and service always more than compensate.
author: David S.

description: We have dined at this restaurant on special occasions over the last 25 years --not birthdays or anniversaries -- just weekend getaways. It has never disappointed us. The escargot is one of the best things I have ever tasted, and the sweetbreads were perfection. The wine list is very conservatively French, but because it is, the wine never disappoints either. I will keep coming here as long as it and I exist.
author: Marcus C.

description: My wife and I ate here on our trip to San Francisco this weekend . The food was amazing and the service was even better.  We both had the 5 course lobster special.  For being a French restaurant the portions were on the large side. The pasta appetizer was one of the best pasta dishes we have have ever tasted. We definitely will be back!
author: Ken M.

description: My husband and I made a same day reservation for the New Year's Eve prix fix menu.  Having passed our party animal prime, we opted for the early (6 p.m.) seating.  Everything was excellent - service, food, and ambience.  The five course menu featured soft shell crab in meuniere sauce, cucumber watercress bisque, smoked salmon salad, a choice of lobster tail or filet mignon, creme brulee or chocolate ganache with creme anglais, and a glass of sparking wine.  I am normally not a fan of soft shell crab (I prefer fresh dungeness), but it was very tasty and the meuniere sauce was delicious (we requested more bread to sop it up - we're not proud).  The bisque was rich, yet refreshing, the smoked salmon salad was perfect.  The combination of salmon, endive, and avocado worked very well together.  The lobster was tender and the filet mignon (ordered rare) was cooked perfectly and was very flavorful.  The creme brulee was a creamy burnt sugar delight, but the ganache (the ganache!) was over the top yummy decadence.  The service was friendly and efficient, but not obtrusive.  And the owner came by each table and chatted with her guests.  Of course there was an added charge to the normal prix fix price for the holiday, but considering it was a holiday, and the level of service and food quality, it was well worth it.
author: Lisa B.

description:
I don't know if this was just an off night (it was sunday night and there were definitely no french chefs or servers to be seen) but I thought this was close to terrible but how expensive it was and how AWFUL the cream sauces were. First of all, all the people in my party ordered different dishes, one of which was supposed to have a truffle sauce, another peppercorn, another rosemary... well, they were all IDENTICAL. Identical. And gross. Sickly sweet, all of us were scrapping the sauce off our meat so we could eat the meat itself. The cuts of meat were good, but again, poorly prepared - overcooked, undersalted, kinda dry...Oh and $35 per plate!
Bummer.
author: C. P.

description:
I rarely if ever eat at French bistros in CA. Our French in SB is Bouchon (not related to the Vegas one to my knowledge but it may be) is extremely expensive but worth it on a special occasion (Valentine's Day, anniversary, birthday). 

In New York, I go to Bistro Chat Noir, Mon Petit Cafe, Quatorze Bis (once). The Upper East Side boasts many excellent French restaurants, not the least of which is Sel y Poivre, an old neighborhood family-owned bistro. It's extremely reasonable--the bargain prix-fixe of the Upper East side for dinner--28.95 for entree, appetizer and dessert! 

But my CT friend who traveled to SF for business a lot at one time always ate here. Just at the bottom of Nob Hill, down from the Mark Hopkins on 900 Pine Street, it's teeny tiny with unusually beautiful and comfortable chairs and tables close together. 

I was absolutely astounded by the food and the prices, far lower than I expected for a place of this caliber. It's 30 years old and you don't survive in the cutthroat restaurant business if you aren't exceptional. 

It's owned by a charming older Asian couple and frequented by a combination of locals and well-to-do tourists. One man came in by himself and ordered a Caesar salad (the best I've ever had, utterly perfect dressing, plenty of shaved cheese and tons of anchovies for just 8 or 9 dollars), a glass of wine and a dessert. 

I was shocked by the size and we were lucky on a Friday night during our mini-vacation to San Francisco for the Afghan Whigs show at the Fillmore (review of this legendary venue forthcoming) to get the last table for two at 8PM. 

My boyfriend had the filet with cognac peppercorn, a generous cut of meat with some potatoes underneath. It was exquisite and entrees come with a cup of soup. The soup of the day was cream of vegetable, just a hint of cream, with a wonderful flavor. 

I never send things back due to temperature but the soup was barely warm so they happily took it back and it returned quite hot. 

The coffee was terrific and strong (I'm wondering if they serve my favorite coffee--Peerless--since that's a SF-based company) but if you demand scalding hot coffee say so when you order. 

J had the best cheesecake I've ever tasted, far lighter than a New York cheesecake like he had at Cafe Majestic the night before. The creme anglaise was so good I could have had a cup of all by itself. 

Best of all for a place of this caliber, there are plenty of 8 and 9 dollar wines by the glass. In New York, it's gotten insane. 14 used to be the most expensive wine by the glass and now it's barely above average at a nice restaurant. 

Hotel bars are notoriously pricey but at the Gramercy Hotel bar (admittedly great), wines start at 13 or 14 and to up to the low 20s. Same with the Peninsula. 

It was an extraordinary meal and with an entree, two soups, a salad, coffee , dessert and one glass of wine just 75 before tip? 

I can't wait to eat there again when I'm hungrier

P.S.: The bathroom is TINY. When I say tiny, I don't mean 3 or 4 feet by 3 or 4 feet. I mean it's like an airplane bathroom, just a bit longer. It's no big thing but it is a bit of a shock.
author: Victoria O.

description: Best sweet breads in SF!! Giraldo is the consummate host who will keep u smiling and ur appetite fulfilled!!
author: Jim B.

description:
This is my third time at Rue Lepic. It's 100 yds from the Fairmont or Mark Hopkins. 

Service is great and food to match. 

Has a very comfortable neighbor ambiance, non touristy and reasonable prices. 

Going back again to this hidden treasure.
author: Jeb J.

description:
TOO MUCH BUTTER

Food:  nice salads, nice soup, but the entrees were drowning in butter---I guess that's the secret of French cooking

Service: very good, very friendly

The place: nice location and setting; they need to work on their ventilation system--kitchen smoke permeates the dining room
author: James M.

description:
We had dinner here on a Wednesday night.  Walked in around 6:35pm, and the restaurant was somewhat empty.  We were able to get seated right away even though we didn't have reservations.

The place is pretty small.  They only had one waiter working.  I'm not sure if it's like that  every night or just weeknights.  The service is decent.

I ordered their caesar salad which was $8.50.  It was a tad small for what they charge.

Our entrees each came with a small bowl of soup (cream of mushroom that day).  We got the boneless breast of duck with an orange sauce ($29) and the grilled tenderloin of beef with a cognac peppercorn sauce ($33).  I thought the steak was very good.  Just the right size.  The peppercorn sauce was very tasty, and there was lots of it (which I like).  It also came with some scalloped potatoes (or was it potatoes au gratin?).  The potatoes were good as well.

We were pretty full, so we didn't have room for dessert.
author: Nina S.

description: I brought my wife to this French restaurant and she loved it. All the menu dishes were delicious. I love their lobster tails. So tasty and juicy. I will definitely come back again.
author: Mark C.

description: Nice cozy spot, very friendly service, and good food. Our table enjoyed the filet mignon, the chicken and duck - all good. I found the wine list to be a bit weak, but otherwise a great neighborhood restaurant.
author: David P.

description: Wonderful experience. Delightful meal. Loved meeting the chef and tasting all the wonderful dishes. Thanks to our chef.
author: Susan D.

description: Our dishes were delicious (seafood, steak). My entree came with a creamy soup which was one of the best I've ever had. The service was outstanding. I love the location on the corner of the street. It's an adorable place.
author: E. N.

description: Five stars for amazing French cuisine, the place is clean, friendly customer service and great location! I will definitely come back. Love it.
author: Mila N.

description: The place is small and cozy, it's perfect for romantic dates. The service is really good. The foods are great, i really like them. You should try the escargot dish, it's  so tasty. I got the duck one, and my boyfriend got the chicken one. Both are good and in love with the portion size. They  also gave us free vegie cream soups. So far so good, We had good time here, and will come back.
author: Vivi C.

description: Restaurant was empty when we arrived at 7 pm. Our server was very nice. We ordered a smoked salmon salad, creamed spinach soup, and a steak. The appetizers came out pretty quickly. As we ate our appetizers, more customers arrived. We waited for our entrees for more than 45 minutes. Other customers who arrived after us ate their entrees before we got ours. We were still waiting for our entrees while customers who arrived 30 minutes after us paid and left. My wife ordered a medium rare filet which arrived rare. Because we had waited so long, we didn't bother to send back. Both of our peppercorn steaks were so drowned in peppercorn sauce, we couldn't even taste the meat. Our friends ordered lamb which was also cooked rare. A disappointing experience that left us disgusted and hungry for something else.
author: Marion Y.

description: A delightful, cozy French restaurant on a quiet corner, a short walk from Union Square. Entrees include homemade soup. Enjoyed a garden salad served chilled with vinaigrette followed by a sumptuous rosemary chicken with fresh veggies (carrots and green beans). The waiter Gerardo was excellent. Attentive and courteous. He even topped off my wine...what a surprise and treat! I'll be returning soon! Thanks for a memorable meal and excellent service!
author: Greg L.

description: This is one my favorite restaurants in the city. I have been going here for the last 10 years. The prix fixed option is definitely the way to go. My favorite is the mushroom pasta and the filet mignon. The entire experience is what makes this place special. From the single chef, to the waiter, to the dozen tables.
author: Paul D.

description:
I was catching up with a friend who was staying at the Four Seasons on Market and we decided to head out for dinner instead of getting hotel food.

Rue Lepic popped up on Yelp and had good reviews and we decided that it would be a enjoyable walk in beautiful SF evening weather. No seriously...I like it when it is a little nippy.

This really was a nice walk and a bit of a workaround up those steep hills which is good because I really worked up an appetite. This is a tiny quaint little restaurant. Service was not that great though. Our waitress was surly and never cracked a smile the whole time we were there.

The food was good. Let me just cut to the chase. The ganache was OMG GOOD. Heaven on earth! Let me back track now. The pasta was delish and the caesar salad was good. The pea soup was all right. Slightly disappointed with the filet mignon. The sauce was not that great. So overall it was a satisfying meal though at $200 (including an avg. bottle of wine) including tip was a little pricey given the overall experience. 

BTW, I think this place has the smallest restroom I have ever seen. You literally have to walk sideways to use it. They might have actually converted a closet. No biggie and I thought it was cool. You know, something different.
author: Sunil R.

description: We have eaten in some of the best including "The French Laundry"! This was one of our favorite restaurants! Great atmosphere, staff and food! This is one of the best! Don't miss this one if ever in San Francisco. We will be there anytime we are in San Francisco!
author: Mark T.

description:
We celebrated my father's 85th birthday last night at Rue Lepic and was extremely impressed by the delicious food. First we parked very close to the restaurant. My father parked in front and we parked less than a half a block away. Every single thing  this the group of six got was very flavorful,cooked perfectly and sublime. The chef has been cooking for 33 years and is incredibly sweet and gracious. The noise levels were not too bad either. It did take a while and was a little understaffed ,but it is a small business so I understand. Also ,I have celiac and was totally accommodated and provided with gluten free food which I really appreciated.
The chef is a true master of her craft.
author: Delisa S.

description:
went here last night with a group for my friends birthday ...

the restaurant is super quiet, and we are not, so I'm pretty sure everyone heard all of our conversations (sorry I'm not sorry). I def wouldn't recommend this for a first date spot, because you may feel kinda awkward. 

the service was not good at all, we were quite disappointed. it took forever to get our drink order, and then they brought us butter but no bread ... we had to ask for it twice. everyone that ordered an entree got a tomato-y soup before hand and she took mine before i was done with it. her attitude about everything was just kinda meh. 

the appetizers were fab ... we got the escargot (it comes over a little pasta with this insane sauce. I highly recommend this) & the smoked salmon (comes over a bed of lettuce with capers and a sauce. I'd also recommend this). when we finally got our bread it was great as well!

we got a few different entrees but they all seemed to come with the same sauce which we all loved. A few of us got the chicken, it was moist and came with yummy potatoes and some green beans and carrots. My boyfriend got the filet and said it was cooked perfectly, medium rare. Another friend got the roasted veal and she loved it. no complaints on those 

we had cupcakes waiting at home, so we chose to skip dessert ... but, it was my friends birthday so they brought out a little chocolate ganache with a candle and we all sang happy birthday. 

The prices match the quality and taste of the food, so we all left happy... just wish they gave better service.

FYI :: if you have to use the bathroom & are remotely claustrophobic, good luck. It's smaller than an airport bathroom.
author: danielle a.

description:
4.5 stars.  It's a lovely, cute place, not surrounded by a lot of other establishments in the immediate vicinity.  For this, I liked it more at the get-go.  The ambiance inside is very charming; quiet, but not too quiet because since there are maybe 10 tables in the restaurant, the background noise is the consistent hum of conversation from other patrons.

I ordered the escargots (which was strangely served over spaghetti, but I really enjoyed it), the filet mignon (which was very flavorful, which it was just a little more tender like most filet mignons), and the creme brulee for dessert, which was excellent.  The temperature of the cream itself was very chilled and refreshing, and the glaze on top was perfect.  One of the better creme brulees I've had!

I've lately been on a French food kick, and Rue Lepic did not disappoint!
author: Mel G.

description:
Rue Lepic is a Nob Hill institution, and one of my favorite places in San Francisco.  The owner of this place has a lot of history.  Google her.  She is an amazing woman.

I come here for the special occasions.  I typically order the chicken which has a delicious creamy/mushroom base.  Very French, and yet so accessible and humble.

 A small table by the glass window, and a view to an old fashioned street in Nob Hill.  It's all about the simple pleasures of life.

Take the woman who truly deserves your heart here.  The "other" women can be taken elsewhere.
author: Kanishk P.

description:
This place is close to me - I should come here more often!  We came here on a night when the Giants were playing so it was probably a little quieter than usual.  We had a lovely meal of vegetable puree soup (soup or salad is included with your entree) - mmm!  Good taste and comforting.  I wanted the lobster tails, but they were out of this so for some reason we were all in the mood for salmon.  I tend to like my salmon more on the plain side because I enjoy the taste of salmon itself.  Rue Lepic's sauce was a little heavy for my taste, but it had good flavoring.  I sopped up the sauce with bread - mmm!  The waiter recommended a nice, buttery chardonnay to go with our salmon.

Service was real nice and attentive, and the chef came by and checked on us, which is always a caring touch.  And yes, the restroom is super tiny, haha.  But it goes with the charm of Rue Lepic.  Definitely a neighborhood plus.
author: Maile N.

description:
A very small and cozy restaurant that is worth a visit. First of all the wine list is not extensive but very good and prices are reasonable. 

The Monthuy's Pere et Fils champagne was very good. 

The salmon according to my better half was "incredible." My chicken was not very tasty and we thought was bland. Perhaps something was left out in the preparation. The soup, Cream of Watercress, was fabulous. 

I would return for a second visit in the future.
author: Harry T.

description:
I'm a vegetarian and came here with a group. There are no vegetarian options on the menu (I came here with a group, did not choose the place myself) and the chef is unable to make anything vegetarian. I ended up asking if they could make something with pasta (used in other dishes) and vegetables (asparagus, green beans, carrotts) and got a tasteless dish that was as good as a dry pasta out of a package. The meat items on the menu were apparently fantastic.
Bottom line - if you're a vegetarian and end up needing to come here, eat before or make plans for after.
author: T K.

description:
I loved their food!
Their food is def. flavorful with lots of sauces. I LOVE that tho. 

I got scallop, which as a special menu- the best scallop ever. The creamy sauce that came with scallops was flavorful with garlic! Not too garlicky, but just enough for me. 
My BF ordered filet mignon and it was saucy too. 
It came with somewhat meatloaf like sauce- but he enjoyed it. He even cleaned the rest of the sauce on a plate with mashed potatoes!!
At the end, our plates were squeaky clean!!

All the Entrees come with soup- which was good too.
I wouldn't go for the course menu- about $60/person, 4~5 courses- because you get full with one entree anyways. 

I took one star off because of the interior and ambiance...
the restaurant is super small and not well decorated. Self portrait of the owner also freaked me out a bit... 
But, food is the most important, so I would def. go again to try something else on the menu.
author: Sora B.

description:
My husband and I had a great dinner here. We had the shrimp salad with a wonderful warm sauce. I had the rack of Lamb with a mushroom sauce and Steve had the veal with another amazing sauce. The chef cooks right inside the restaurant so that you can watch all the sauces being made.
Highly recommend  this locals favorite.
Steve and Lynn Putman
author: Steve, Lynn And Kaitlyn P.

description:
Cute neighborhood restaurant.  Small dining room but we went on a week night so it wasn't that busy.  It was hot inside... no air conditioning and it was on one of those rare warm nights in SF.

The food is very good and prices reasonable for San Francisco.  The poulet was very flavorful and perfectly cooked... not dry at all.  The venison was also good as well as the soup.  The owner was nice enough to give us a free cheesecake for dessert.  He recognized me as living in the neighborhood.  I always walked by this restaurant and never thought about stopping by until I had out of town guests that night and didn't feel like driving.  I wished I had dinned their sooner and will definitely stop by again.
author: Angelique B.

description:
Wonderfully unpretentious and intimate restaurant.  Service was well paced for ordering and serving.  You didn't feel like you were waiting and you felt you could have conversation and catch up with friends.

The food was delicious and presentation was beautiful.  Very flexible chef's selection menu that allows you to try any entree or dessert.  I enjoyed the sweetbreads even after the generous portions of pasta, soup and salad.

Best cheesecake I have ever had - amazingly light and creamy - almost like a panna cotta.  Passionfruit mousse was my favorite but all the desserts were perfect.

I have wanted to come here for awhile and was delighted it lived up to my expectations.
author: Jennie M.

description:
I don't eat a lot of French food, but I assume this is as good as it gets! I ordered of the Chef's Menu.  An incredible starter, Seafood Pasta. Wow! Then the daily soup special..INcredible, next a caesar salad....it was okay, then the roasted veal in a truffle and mushroom sauce....Out of this world!!  the Creme Brulee didn't do it for me, but I'm not a dessert eater... I had a few glasses of the Rue Sud Pinot Noir and it was very tasty.

All in all an amazing place.  And a pleasant walk from Union Square.  

The walk justify's what you are about to eat!
author: Chuck C.

description:
My husband and I wanted to go to a fancy smancy restaurant and found RL on Yelp and it looked fancy enough for us so we checked it out.

We were the first to arrive at the restaurant a few minutes before it opened up and we were greeted with do you have a reservation? We stated that we did not, which didn't seem to be a problem and we were seated in the "nicest" part of restaurant according to the owner.

My hubby had the rack of lamb that came with yellow rice and veggies + a glass of cabernet and I had the rosemary chicken that came with veggies and a touch of saucy mash potatoes. I'm seriously impressed by the amazing food and this just might be the best dinner I've ever had. 

The two things I would say that need improvements would be the restaurant itself. It's very outdated and the other would be the servers were stiff to the point where the service was impersonal and a tad pompous. I also noticed that my waiter's attire was outdated as well and unclean, which isn't a big deal but something that should be looked into.

Overall my husband and I did enjoy our meal and will certainly be making our way back to RL sometime in the near future. Our total bill with tax + tip included was $75 for 2 entrees and 1 glass of wine and we both thought it was well worth it.

Great job Rue Lepic!
author: V W.

description:
Adorable.

The staff couldn't have been more helpful and attentive.

From fresh warm bread, to creamy corn soup, to a decadent serving of tender salmon - every course of our meal was presented beautifully and served with love.

The passionfruit mousse was the highlight of my meal. Dreamy, fluffy, and packed with flavor. My mom and I dove into that thing with fervent bites, and in a matter of seconds, the plate was barren.

For a cozy, charming, and lovely dinner - prepared with care - Rue Lepic is your spot.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: My husband and I were visiting from out of town and chose this place because he had eaten here ten years ago while at a conference. To his surprise it was the Same cook who was there ten years ago! When we came in we were immediately greeted by a beautiful smiling women who was very kind and gracious to us throughout our visit. We had the smoked salmon as an appetizer and the chicken and the duck for dinner. This also came with fresh bread and soup (which I believe she said was squash soup). We finished with coffee, espresso and an outstanding dessert of fruit with cream (literally the best dessert I have ever had!!)  Everything was absolutely AMAZING!! The atmosphere was beautiful and calming and romantic. Our glasses were never empty, and the service was wonderful. All of this cost us approximately $83. We have paid well over a hundred dollars for much worse. Don't miss out on this sweet little place! I can't wait to go back!!
author: Emmi K.

description: Great service and great food. Our family of 5 really enjoyed this especially considering my kids were not sure what French was .... plus I have a kid who only eats very plain food.   They made him food off the menu.  Food was very tasty !!  Our server was great and had such a good demeanor about him - Made the place feel really homely.  Great food was enjoyed all around by my family.
author: Hilton B.

description: What a great find! My girlfriend and I were looking for a romantic spot near our hotel in Union Square last weekend and through Yelp we found this gem. We opted for the Chef's menu (w/ out the lobster) and we were thoroughly impressed. The seafood pasta starter was excellent, as were the soup du jour and salad courses. She chose the Filet au poive and I the rack of lamb. Desserts of chocolate ganache and cheesecake exceeded expectations. This was a perfect cap to our night of cocktails at the Tonga Room and a fine French meal!
author: Charles D.

description:
Waited to be placed even with empty seats. The plate was greasy. 
For a real French culinary experience you should go to cafe Claude instead.
author: David C.

description: This restaurant was a great choice. The staff was amazing and when we said we had theater tickets they made sure to get us out on time. The salmon and steak were both excellent and it was great to eat at a neighborhood place with a long history. We will be back for sure.
author: V M.

description:
Simply amazing. It's been 8 years since I last was there-until this Sunday. The food hasn't changed a bit and it still superb in every way & worth every penny. I love support a chef who is truly passionate about her restaurant (and beautifully dressed too). She is so personable to visit every table asking about your meal and kindly held the door for us as we exited. 

This is the perfect, romantic date spot. It definitely reminds me of a European restaurant. Needless to say, you won't be disappointed with the meal, service, or ambiance.
author: Lindsey R.

description:
Simply AMAZING! Small, romantic, and quaint. No frills, no scene. Just REAL GOOD FOOD. 

My girlfriend and I went here for our NYE dinner since we opted to not spend $300 just to get into a club/venue. We decided to go to a nice place and spend that money on food instead. Best $87 dollars of my life. 

Walking into the place felt "Asian". Don't ask me to explain that but if you are Asian, then you know what I'm talking about. The owner was this cute little Japanese lady.  She definitely made it very homey and comfortable. Very friendly staff. The woman chef was amazing! She was situated to where you could see her cook the food rather in the back of the place. So you can see for yourself that she prepares everything in the best way. 

 We had a 6 course prix fixed meal. 6 courses for $87 plus champagne! What a deal! Everything was amazing. I was full by the 3rd course (I wore a skin tight dress which did not let my stomach expand whatsoever). I chose the lobster tail rather than the filet. They must have had alot of really big lobster tails (I heard the waiter mentioning it), but the thing was as big as a quart milk carton. Freaking huge! The champagne was amazing and they did not skimp on it. 

The dessert was the best part. We had the creme brulee and the fruit cup (dunno what it was called). The fruits were all so sweet and fresh. It was drizzled with some sort of sauce. Mmmmm. The creme brulee was orgasmic. I seriously thought about stripping out of my black dress and eating the entire supply.  

All in all, I loved my experience here. I will definately come back for their usual 5 course for $50ish. It's worth the money and the walk up the damn hill. Best way to ring in the new year, with your face in some good food!
author: Katie Anne N.

description: My husband had a business dinner here, and he asked me to tag along. A small corner restaurant surrounded by steep streets. Trust me, don't expect to find parking easily, but don't discourage yourselves to try this place as well. Anyways, inside the restaurant, there were only around 8 tables, and the kitchen was very visible from where we sat. The whole ambiance made me think it was a house-turned-restaurant type. It was cute. Everything that the chef cooked permeated every corner of the small room. It smelled so good. The downside was, the aroma clung on my hair and clothes. LOL. That's not really bad, was it? I ordered the Chef's Menu and it included a bowl of Mushroom Soup, Seafood Pasta, Caesar Salad, Filet Mignon, Bordeaux (wine), Le Ganache Au Chocolat for dessert and Capuccino. C'est si bon! Et c'etait gratuit. Merci pour le patron de mon mari. :-) See, eating in a French restaurant brings out my French. LOL No, seriously, it was that good. You should try it.
author: Sonnia K.

description: The dinner started with a wonderful bowl of cauliflower soup and hot crusty bread. They had me there! I ordered the salmon and it was fork tender and very, very good. The green beans were tender and flavorful without being soft or over cooked. The meal was worth the price. I'll definitely go again when I am in San Francisco.
author: Rhonda R.

description:
A well-meaning but mediocre restaurant. Maybe the tourists will keep it going. 

Since it's often hard to figure out which reviewers know their food and which don't, I'll say which SF French restaurants I do like: Chez Papa and Zazie. (No, I haven't tried any of the really expensive ones.) Readers can decide whether my opinion is worth taking seriously. 

General point: Food was overspiced, in some cases wantonly so. 

Lentil soup: blended smooth, but had too much salt-and pepper mixture--left a harsh aftertaste in the back of the throat. 

Le Poulet avec Rosemary: again, overspiced. (The beans and carrots were cooked perfectly; small compensation.) 

However, the poulet was a miracle of restraint compared to the Filet Mignon, which had been drowned in Worcestershire sauce. I think I outgrew this style of cooking in fourth grade. Maybe fifth. Had we not been in a rush to see our show, we would have sent it back.  The cut of meat was not particularly flavorful, either. At $32, this was a huge disappointment. 

Bottom line: if you want mediocre food before taking in a show in the theater district, save your money and go to Lori's Diner. 

(Of course the service was pleasant, but I've never seen the point of giving and withholding stars based on service.)
author: Nat C.

description:
I love SAUCED up french food and this place gave me just that. 

Went for the obvious choice of the prix fixed menu and loved each dish. Was pleasantly surprised at how much food it came with as many French places can be pretty stingy with their serving size. So big plus for that!

The restaurant itself is pretty casual but it's small and cozy enough to make a great date night if needed. The wait staff and owner were also super nice which makes you like this place even more. Overall, a super cute restaurant that provides great food for a really good price.
author: Teese N.

description: What are all these people who give Rue Lepic 4 or 5 stars thinking?  Where do they normally eat?  We experienced amateurish service, sweetbreads that were unrecognizable rubbery discs with heavy breading, tasteless steamed vegetables.  For the money you can do SO much better in the Bay Area.
author: Ann T.

description:
I came here after a fantastic show of Book of Mormon with my family, and we were as hungry as ever. We had already made reservations & it was a Wednesday night, so it wasn't too busy but the ambiance was good. For a 3 person staff, the service and food were both excellent. I have only been to a couple other French restaurants, none super expensive, but I think it is the best one I have been to so far!

The soup, creamed cauliflower, was DELISH! Great with the hot bread served to us.

I order the Filet Mignon, liked the sauce although it was a little reminiscent of a bbq sauce flavor, but nonetheless fantastic. 
My mom ordered the Rosemary Chicken, boasting its flavor and tenderness. 
My sister ordered the veal, which seemed a little subpar compared to our meals, but had a great sauce. 
The duck ordered by my dad was tasty, but not as good as expected.  
Carrot and beans were amazing sides, as well as the scalloped potatoes. 

We ordered a creme brulee and mango mousse for dessert. Both were good as usual, nothing horrible or extraordinary. 

Overall, the staff was extremely nice and did exceptionally well for only have one chef. Food was served at a perfect time, hot, and delicious. I would come back again to try the lamb or seafood pasta!
author: Anika B.

description:
Thirteen of us had dinner there tonight, special occasion, and everything was terrific. Great food, great service, fun atmosphere, just a wonderful experience. What a gem.

John F
author: John F.

description: Just a really nice mom and pop restaurant in Nob Hill. Attentive, personal, quaint. Always excellent food. Can't go wrong here.  Nice wines. One of my nob hill favorites.
author: Sluggo S.

description:
Very disappointing!  My husband and I had eaten there about 28 years ago and we decided to take our daughter and her husband for what we remembered as a pleasant dining experience.  Sadly the service was abominable, the food was fair, and although it had a small restaurant atmosphere, that did not make up for the poor service and average quality food.To begin with, after being seated we waited 1/2 hour before our drink orders were taken.  The waits between courses were long and no one ever looked to make eye contact with us.  
      Specifically, the salads were pitiful and appeared to have been prepared yesterday, the main courses were passable, and the creme brûlée was tiny and unremarkable. I would not recommend this to anyone!
author: Georgia C.

description: Extremely small, cozy, and romantically dimmed just right at the corner of PIne and Mason. Call in advance to request for the table at the corner. You can not help but notice people walking their dogs in this neighborhood. The food is consistently delectable and at a reasonable price. Don't miss the seafood pasta and the filet mignon. The only complaint is the parking.
author: Peter L.

description:
I've been here twice and both times my dinner left something to be desired.

The first time I chose the salmon.  It was a good thing we both ordered it because it was on the fishy side and no matter how much listerine and toothpaste I used I still had the flavor with me the next morning.  The soup that accompanied it was a watery, non-exciting non-recalling soup of the day.  

The Caesar salad had no flavor, although the romaine was crisp.  

The second time was a bit of an odd experience.  We were there for nearly 2 hours.  It took an hour from when we ordered before we were served.  My partner ordered chicken with no sauce.  The waiter came back once to ask for our orders a second time around.  We joked about them killing the chicken in the back before they cooked it.  Then the meal comes out and he was served fish of the day smothered in sauce. ??? I guess they had to go fishing instead.   By then we didn't want to wait another hour for them to correct the order.   

Not sure about this place.  Its one of those little romantic and quaint places in SF that's been around forever.  The food is okay. It's more of a romantic, date night place that's good for presentation or last minute reservations.
author: Jamil S.

description:
Never wrote even one review in my life 
Can not even describe how bad it was. It is not cozy, it is crowdy
It is not French food , it is just a very average dinner, extremely overpriced, precooked
Salad ans soup , which was served immediately, means was standing somewhere waiting for the victims
Very unprofessional stuff
Just meat was ok
Never ever again
If you know what good French ristorante means, do not stop just pass by and find better place to waste your time and money
author: Zhanna V.

description:
Nice small restaurant!  Came here on a Thursday night and there was plenty of street parking at 7:30.

The bread was tasty and the salad was just ok, nothing special. I got the duck which was good while my friend got the rack of lamb which was also delicious (I usually can't stand the gamy taste of it). Portions were generous that you will leave with a full tummy. The highlight was probably the seafood pasta however, it was cooked very well.

When I was there on a Thursday night at around 8, there were maybe 2 other tables occupied. Within 20 minutes, the restaurant was empty except me and my friend so the ambiance was !@#$ing great but I can see how it can get noisy if the restaurant had a full house.

TLDR: This is a very safe restaurant so to speak, everything was well done but not mind blowing. Not sure if I would come here again though with so many other restaurants in the city.
author: Aaron H.

description:
I brought my mum here on her visit to SF and it was Mother's Day. Perfect setting in this small cosy restaurant tucked away in the heart of Nob Hill. It was her day and I wanted to give her the most personal one to one time, both with mother and daughter.
